texts.shortText: Medium-sized shark with five gill slits, large dorsal fins without anterior spines, second dorsal fin almost as large as first. Snout bluntly rounded and mouth wide. Teeth small with a narrow erect cusps. Colour grey, usually with numerous small black spots (sometimes sparse or even absent, especially in juveniles).
Up to 208 cm length with a mass up to 50 kg.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Angola to Eastern Cape, rarely reported in southern KwaZulu-Natal.

Shallow waters over both rocky reefs and sand to a depth of about 50 m. Generally remains close to the bottom and may shelter in crevices, but mainly active at night. Usually solitary or in small groups, but can form larger aggregations in summer, probably associated with reproduction.

Fairly slow-growing species, females maturing at about 145 cm and an age of about 15 years and males at 125–135 cm at an age of about 11–13 years. Maximum lifespan at least 25 years.

Feeds on larger benthic invertebrates, such as crabs, lobsters and cephalopods, as well as on bony fish. The main prey item of smaller individuals is the Cape rock crab Guinusia chabrus. Larger individuals take a wider variety of prey, mostly bony fish but including guitarfish and catsharks.

Ovoviviparous, females giving birth from May to August and producing 5–15 pup per litter, larger females generally producing more young per litter. Young are born at a length 30–31 cm. Due to the long gestation time females only reproduce once every 2–3 years.

Can be confused with Smooth-hound shark Musteus mustelus, which is similar in size and can also have black spots. These are fewer and larger though, and in that species the second dorsal fin is much smaller than the first.
